Award.AwardTitle: The NuPRISM Detector: Extending the Sensitivity of Neutrino Oscillation Experiments
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports work to understand neutrinos: the smallest but most common massive particle in the universe. Although there are a billion neutrinos for every more well-known electron or proton, neutrinos interact only via the so-called "weak" force: so they rarely bump into anything, even the detectors designed to study them. That means they are also the least well understood of the fundamental particles. One of the big mysteries in neutrino science is how they change (or "oscillate") from one type to another. The study of neutrinos has progressed rapidly over the past 25 years. The ultimate goal of neutrino oscillation experiments such as this is to determine whether neutrinos and antineutrinos behave differently. This can tell us about the evolution of the universe a fraction of a second after the big bang, and provide clues about why the universe is currently filled with matter and not anti-matter.

Neutrino oscillation experiments produce neutrinos in one particular type (referred to as flavor), which is measured at a near detector close to the neutrino production point, and search for the disappearance of this flavor and/or the appearance of a new neutrino flavor at a far detector. The NuPRISM detector, which this award will develop, is a new type of near detector that measures the produced neutrinos over a wide range of angles, which provides a method for measuring the energy of the neutrinos with unprecedented precision. This new technique has the potential to extend the reach of current and future neutrino oscillation experiments.This project includes enrichment activities for high school students interested in pursuing careers in STEM fields. Students from local school districts will be selected to spend a day at Stony Brook University learning about scientific research, attending demonstrations, and meeting with graduate students and faculty.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of long-baseline neutrino oscillation experiments is to precisely measure several of the last few unknown parameters of the standard model of particle physics, including the parameter deltaCP, which determines the degree to which matter and anti-matter behave differently. These experiments produce a beam of neutrinos that travel to a far detector several hundred kilometers away, and search for a change (oscillation) of one flavor of neutrino to another. The precision of these experiments is currently limited by our understanding of neutrino interactions with atomic nuclei, which can obscure the relationship between the particles produced in a neutrino-nucleus interaction, and the energy of the neutrino, which is essential for measuring neutrino oscillations.

The NuPRISM Detector is a new experimental technique that can provide strong constraints on neutrino-nucleus interactions by using a mobile near detector that can take data at many positions off-axis from the primary neutrino beam direction. As the detector moves off-axis, the neutrino energy is reduced, which allows the detector to sample a variety of different neutrino energies. These measurements can then be used to determine the relationship between neutrino energy, and the particles that are seen in the detector.

This award was used to develop the NuPRISM concept for the next generation of long-baseline neutrino experiments, Hyper-Kamiokande and DUNE. This work demonstrated that a NuPRISM detector is needed to improve upon the precision of existing measurements in order to place strong constraints on the measured neutrino oscillation parameters. As a result of this effort, both of the next generation experiments have adopted NuPRISM detectors in their respective neutrino beamlines, which will allow for unprecedented measurements of the last few poorly known fundamental parameters in the standard model.

This award also supported a program to bring groups of high needs high school students to Stony Brook University for an interactive electronics design project in which students constructed a home security system component. This provided students with hands-on experience in how electronics components are assembled into an operating device for an interesting and practical application.
